A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details or describe particular events if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
SASKATOON, Saskatchewan.

1. Your full name: Dora Amelia Doolittle
2. Your address: Orange Lake
3. Date: May 24, 1963
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Shillier, Bruce Edward County, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? Eli Lincoln Doolittle, Carpenter & Contractor
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): To Colonies P.O. (date?) Please - W.T. Nov., 1895
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible: At Home Ont. Started to school there.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would prefer not or you may use "I was a small child," "I was in my teens," etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
My parents were planning to go out to the West. We had heard about the good land and the opportunity to make a living. We wanted to be free from the responsibilities of working on a farm.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

I learned about my Grandfather James McKee hard neighbour who had "gone and West" and by telling him and visiting back to Ontario had spread the good news to all, of the homesteads and good soil all for free and we will work and make many sacrifices. My Grandfather had a family of 11 children and went to settle in a new place.

Travelled with my mother, 3 brothers and 1 sister and my Aunt (my brother's wife). We had 7 children, but the first child died.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We left from the home of a neighbour on the farm with the family who was going to the West. We travelled along the road that was covered in snow.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Nothing very exciting did my Aunt have to say about her trip.

For our own safety we took the train and walked. We camped at night in the tourist camps. We also had to walk through the forest.

My mother was with us when we arrived in the area.

At station where we met a French settlement on the edge of the large French settlement around called new French Church.

My parents went straight to Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

I don't recall very much about the land and house but I have some old photos of the family who purchased it.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

The summer we came out in May. It was particularly hot so Grandpa had worked so hard to have the family all together once more. We attended school in the homestead.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Grandma Doolittle thought it would work out alright in the spring.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

We traveled with my mother, father, and my aunt (my brother's wife). We had two children, two dogs, and the horse.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

We left from the home of a neighbor on the 4th of January with the horse and buggy and a covered wagon team of driving horses. There was also a covered wagon trailer attached to the old model carriage.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Nothing very exciting befell my family during our journey westward except for sleeping in the train cars and having to deal with the cold and harsh weather conditions.

My mother was very ill and had to be carried at all times when we traveled. Also, my father became ill and had to be carried as well.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

We stayed in a small town called "Moose Jaw" for about a week before heading north.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

We settled near the town of "Moose Jaw" and took up land there.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

We lived in a small town called "Moose Jaw" for about a week before heading north.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

We came to Western Canada because Grandpa had worked so hard to save the family's money over many years.

Your children were welcome to me, but not too much trouble.

The Indians were always friendly to us, and they were always very kind.

We were always taught to respect the Indian people and never to be afraid of them. They always remembered any kindnesses they came through our hands—before the coming of the white man.

They came to the United States, their friend and relatives. Later, they came to Canada, where they settled and raised families.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came here?

Everything. There were no roads, churches, schools, railroads, telephones, telegraphs, or money. We had to build our own homes, farms, stores, and paths and lots of them. Prairie and the Morse building and streets were built by hand. We helped other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

My name is George Smith. I am 85 years old. My son Kenneth also lives in Moose Jaw. They may help fill this out.

If someone else has filled in this questionnaire for you, please have this person give name and address here:

No one mentioned. Fill a form like this can't begin to capture the experiences of early days. When we moved here, we had to work hard and travel far from home. Our neighbors, early settlers who traveled long distances to find shelter, worked hard for church services.
1. Early remembrances of my two Uncle's living here in Nebraska. I would be 8 years old then. It was my first time or only morning and someone held me up to show them land they had seen going "Far away." To whom? Friends and Uncle John even when families were living for some place else.

"Why were they going?" Several years earlier neighbors the Smiths had gone away and went to Nebraska and homesteaded there. When they came back to Nebraska for a visit mutually the whole community was friendly interested until they heard of and met my parents of the "free" farmland and cheap homesteaded duties. The land doctoring made them rich in the West. He usually met what money raised and many they could own the country land holding they had in Nebraska and went to Nebraska.

The name "Manitoba" was still used for many years when referring to what is now the other three Western provinces. I don't know how far North they used to go. (I have many old letters here from 1889 and later) although so many difficult feet appear but
1. Early reminiscences of my two Uncle's coming home from Canada. I was about 8 years old then. If was mighty late in July when they came home. They were going "far away" to where Grandpa and Uncle John were.

They had fond memories of those "innocent" times when families were living for some place else.

"Why were they going?" Several years earlier neighbors the Mylers had gone away and tried to become free homesteaders. When they came back to Orleans for a visit mutually the whole community very greatly interested with them. There was much talk and discussion for prize and during homestead duties. The land was taken up and given away. It usually was what many raised and many who could not afford to pay for land building they built outbuildings and went to Illinois to the same time. They came back to Illinois and went to Western Kansas. I think they knew how far from Mexico they would go. (I have no idea where they came from in 1889 and they returned to many different post offices.)

The above should answer the question of why I came out west late. James McKee was my grandfather and he came out to Morden. Then he met my grandmother's cousins on his way out (the Hutchinsons). He had also visited at Winnipeg to the Bandos who had the hotel there. They were also our neighbours. Mr. Band wanted girls to help in the hotel so his visit had later results. Two of his daughters did come out to Morden and later to Wpg., where one of them met and married a young man from Berlin Oul who was working on a store. However, Grandpa proceeded further on and finally hired out to a farmer in Man for the crop season. This earning enough to buy his first team of oxen and wagon. He and the other young men who came from out with him then drove out to meet where Forget Lake now is and selected their homestead; then returned by way of Old Coulee Carlyle to fall on their land and also for an older Uncle who was to come out too. They spent the winter working on farms in Man and next spring when the grass was high enough to graze oxen on Grandpa

drove out to the homestead. The other man came later and after they had done some breaking they put up two log buildings very small (the space between was used for grainary later by closing it in) One end the men used for house - the other end was for the oxen. Thus they wintered doing their own cooking and taking bread (Grandpa finally got to be the best bread maker around, they said.) It apparently meant all sunshine homesteading with oxen. If the flies bothered they just worked out in the sloughs, snow and all and many times no persuasion could get them out. A post office was established about 7 miles from their place. The mail came from Woronoco. The old letters show postmarks of Demington, Percy, Carlyle and Coban all on the same envelope. Apparently all the mail was sorted out at each stop and post marked there then sent on to the next etc. But the mail did arrive! Does this get too detailed? Well that was how homesteading was without the women to do women's work the men who came alone had to concern from the field work and get their own meals and all.
and after they had done some building they put up their big building very small (the place between the road and the river) by buying land. One day the man said his name - the other end was for the town.

They bought property, buying their own cooking and taking care of the house. They bought the best materials they could find (because family got to be the best they could).

The next day they moved into their new home. They moved all the things from the old house to the new one. They moved all the furniture and everything else.

When this fell into place? Well that was how the town started. It was nothing but women who worked hard to make the town grow. The men who came alone had to come to pay the rent work and get their own meals and work.
To make a long story short, Uncle John did come out finally in 1891 and he also worked in Manitoba to get money to carry on with. Money was just one thing there wasn't very much to be had in those days. Also they had crop failures through hail and frost and long hauls to nearest point of shipment and low prices. No wonder it took so long to get enough to bring a family of 10 out. The older ones had got married, my mother being one of them. In 1895, the two Uncles mentioned in the opening up the pioneer story came out West and they too worked for older settlers farther North so they could get horses and equipment. They really didn't suffer from idleness. With sons now to help Grandpa they put up a good sized log house with cellar and upstairs, quite comfortable, but still the money was scarce as ever, but gradually they exchanged oxen for horses and gathered around them cattle, pigs, fowl and garden and by 1896 had sent for 3 more of the family to come out including Grandma. It was a day of great rejoicing to have 7 of them now

From what I have been told and from letters and a small diary of one of my aunts (the one who bought the feather ticks & pillows on the train for comfort) I have pieced together the life that was lived on this particular homestead in Area 405.

It would take books not a few pages to enumerate all the change that "homesteading" made in the lives of the people. I have several old letters here, by now telling of how hard it was to get enough money to send back to Indiana for the rest of the family. They just wanted any money left after they paid for seed, house, wagons, machinery to put in crops, and all things necessary. Their nearest town was thirty miles away, and it was about twenty-five years ago when they had crops fail several years and it was all they could do to save and for trying to get a crop the next year. I also remember a neighbor of Grandpa's who came back to Indiana because he knew people and he came back to my folks to tell us of Grandpa and Uncle John and how they helped him out there from the very beginning. The situation didn't bother them, and they had plenty of work and were looking for a way to help him out.

It began to look as if Grandpa wasn't going to have his family all together at least for a while. Lonely still, and Uncle John and Uncle Jim worked very hard, seven years of hard work, and lonely times. He was worried about how he needed all of them to help him make a good home. Finally, he had two big teams big enough and cellar big enough to hold lots of potatoes.
That day went by very quickly though, and I was eager to get back home. I had made it easier for them to get along with their work after my other two weeks had gone out too.

It began to look as if Grandpa was going to have his family all together at last after lonely stuff and Uncle Johnny and John worked away at least 7 years of hard work and lonely time. He wrote so much of how he needed all of them to help him make a good home. Finally he had his top house big enough and cellar big enough to hold lots of potatoes, had gardens ready, cows, pigs, hens and horses. He had sold his oxen. Often I have heard them talk how happy they were together and everything going so well after Grandma, Uncle Arthur & Aunt Anna were there in July 1898.

Till Grandpa died a cyclone blew the roof off the house and he was standing holding his pony at the door and the roof fell on him.

It made a very sad home and my Grandmother and Uncle then wanted my folks and my other aunt and Uncle to come over. Then remember all the letters coming as I had started to school by that time.

I have been very busy lately, working hard to earn money for my family. We now live in Idaho City, and I am grateful for this opportunity.

It's hard to think about the future, but I am determined to provide for my loved ones. I have a good job, and I am thankful for the support of my family.

The house we rent is small, but it is comfortable and cozy. My children love playing outside, and I try to make sure they have enough space to run around.

My husband works long hours, but he always makes time for us. He is a hard worker, and I admire his dedication.

We are planning to move soon, and I am excited to see what the future holds. I am grateful for the support of my family and friends, and I am confident that we will be able to overcome any challenges that come our way.
There were only four of us, including my mother and father, who were going to settle in the country. They thought there would be a good chance to build up homes and other settlers were going there too, so they sent for us.

At last came the day when the packing was all done, my little dog was given to a neighbour to keep and the little girl, James' wife, and the family wrote me and said they were going to go by train and my two brothers who were attending school.

We went to stay with friends who were going to drive us to take the train. I remember the fun we had that night. After we were sent upstairs to bed there was many a shout of "Quiet up there!" Then their Daddies shout extra loud "If I come up there etc etc."

Finally sleep came and so did early morning long before the sun was up. We were dressed extra warmly and seemed to be taking so many clothes with us. The Surrey with the fringe on top with a high stepping team of roan horses (fours) was brought to the door. We said good-bye to all and soon were on our way. The horses with their fine shoes on their feet made such music on the hard road. I never forgot that early drive.

If the trickster (as he often did) and went on a kicking spree, he would always stop if we hollered "Whoa" which happened if we upset the cart. Going to school at least wasn't dull. He might be going along just enjoying everything when suddenly a prairie chicken might jump or rather flop right up in his face and he would stop so suddenly we would likely land on top of him, but "Whoa" kept him in position until we got ourselves back in the cart and on our way. (I don't believe a school bus could be as unpredictable!)

By 1908 I was ready for high school but had only school in the summer. Mr. Vivian was our school Inspector for several years. It was decided I should go to Arcola High School so I went and lived with Mr. Anderson at the C.P.R. Station. They treated me well and were interested in my progress at school. In 1910 I received my third class diploma and went to Regina Normal School for the third class session and took my first school that fall at Vincent Lake.

Social life on the prairies at that time was such that I could have attended a dance or party every night but as I was paid to teach school I needed only a few nights in succession of dancing until I knew Friday nights and Saturday nights were the time I would allot to that pastime; I wouldn't endure being half asleep all day as dances then were all night affairs. I taught then for several years on that Third Class Certificate (until 1916-1917), on extensions granted to me by my School Inspectors recommendation to the Dept. of Education. Then in 1917 I attended the Normal School for Third Class Teachers, and received my second Third Class Certificate Apr 28, 1917 valid until June 30, 1919. Then I received further extensions of my Third Class Certificate until Dec 21, 1923. After that time no further extensions could be granted to me and I again went to work as Assistant in a Municipal Office where I worked for several years including the drought years and relief work in the office.

Since 1949 I stayed at home to care for my parents. Dad died in 1950 and Mother in 1958. Now I live alone and have several hobbies which keep me interested. Collect rocks, stamps, coins and curiosities.

Some record of memories of pioneer days I will record here for posterity, but not right now. I have had enough of looking back for the present.
